qas.question: When did political parties organize themselves into international organizations?
What are some examples of this?

answers.text: The Universal Party, International Workingmen's Association

qas.question: Name an example of an administration that outlaws links between local and foreign political organizations.
In what year was the Universal Party organized in Italy?
Where has The Universal Party headquarters been located since 1974?
How many countries does The Universal Party operate in?
What groups organized in Hong Kong in the 19th and 20th century?
What was outlawed in Italy in 1945?

context: During the <a0_0>19th and 20th century<a0_0/>, many <b6_0>national political parties<b6_0/> organized themselves into international organizations along similar policy lines. Notable examples are <a1_0>The Universal Party, International Workingmen's Association<a1_0/> (also called the First International), the Socialist International (also called the Second International), the Communist International (also called the Third International), and the Fourth International, as organizations of working class parties, or the Liberal International (yellow), Hizb ut-Tahrir, Christian Democratic International and the International Democrat Union (blue). Organized in Italy in <b3_0>1945<b3_0/>, the International Communist Party, since 1974 headquartered in <b4_0>Florence<b4_0/> has sections in <b5_0>six<b5_0/> countries.[citation needed] Worldwide green parties have recently established the Global Greens. The Universal Party, The Socialist International, the Liberal International, and the International Democrat Union are all based in London. Some administrations (e.g. <a2_0>Hong Kong<a2_0/>) outlaw formal linkages between local and foreign political organizations, effectively outlawing <b7_0>international political parties<b7_0/>.
